column1: iti atha vā yaḥ punar ābhimānikaḥ śrutamātrakeṇa jānīyad ahaṃ vijñaptimātratāyāṃ śuddhāyāṃ sthita iti tadgrahavyudāsārtham āha /
column2: But If one Even if he has heard that this is pure consciousness, and puts an object of meditation before him, he still does not remain in pure consciousness.

column1: ādi / vijñaptimātram evedaṃ artharahitaṃ na bāhyo 'rtho 'stīty evam upalambhato grahaṇataḥ citrīkaraṇata ity artho 'grata ity abhimukhaṃ [Tvbh_136] sthāpayann iti yathāśrutaṃ manasā bahuprakāratvād yogācārālambanānāṃ kiṃcid ity āhāsthisaṃkalikaṃ vā vinīlakaṃ vā vipūyakaṃ vā vipaḍumakaṃ vā vyādhmātakādikaṃ vā tanmātre nāvatiṣṭhate vijñānopalambhāprahāṇāt /
column2: Or A conceited person could think on the basis of mere communication, he abides in pure vijnäptimātratā, to exclude this opinion he says: 'If one too', etc. 'This is only pure consciousness without an object, there is no external object This by upalambha, ie grahaņa 'apprehension ', cittikarana 'mental appropriation' 'before' i.e. 'standing up' according to Scripture because of the multiplicity of mind any object of Yogācāra, viz. asthisamkalika, nilaka, puyaka, vipadumaka or vyädhmataka etc. 'yet he does not remain in pure awareness' because the perception of awareness has not disappeared.

column1: kadā punar vijñānagrāhasya prahāṇaṃ cittadharmātāyāñ ca pratiṣṭhito bhavatīty ata āha /
column2: But when does the grasping of consciousness disappear, or does it stand firmly in pure consciousness? He answers: ib.Undifferentiated pure consciousness.

column1: yadā tv ālambanaṃ jñānaṃ naivopalabhate tadā / sthitaṃ vijñaptimātratve grāhyābhābhāve tadagrahāt // 28
column2: When consciousness does not perceive any object at all, then it stands firmly in pure consciousness, because in the absence of an object such is not grasped.

column1: yasmin kāle deśanālambanaṃ avavādālambanaṃ prākṛtaṃ vā rūpaśabdādyālambanaṃ jñānaṃ bahiś cittān nopalabhate na paśyati na gṛhṇāti nābhiniviśate yathābhūtārthadarśanān na tu jātyandhavat tasmin kāle vijñānagrāhasya prahāṇaṃ svacittadharmatāyāṃ ca pratiṣṭhito bhavati /
column2: At which time the consciousness does not perceive, does not see, does not apprehend, does not fully surrender to an object of sermon, instruction, or natural object like color, sound, etc., outside the mind, because it sees the truth, but not how one born blind, at that time the comprehension of consciousness wanes and it stands firmly in the dharmatā of his citta.

column1: atraiva kāraṇam āha / grāhyābhāve tadagrahād iti / (28d)
column2: The reason for this: 'because in the absence of an object, such is not recorded'.

column1: grāhye sati grāhako bhavati na tu grāhyābhāva iti / grāhyābhāve grāhakābhāvam api pratipadyate / na kevalaṃ grāhyābhāvam /
column2: When there is an object there is also a subject, but not when there is none; therefore he recognizes that when there is no object there is also no subject, not only that there is then no apprehension.

column1: evaṃ hi [Tvbh_138] samasamālambyālambakaṃ nirvikalpaṃ lokottaraṃ jñānam utpadyate / grāhyagrāhakābhiniveśānuśayāḥ prahīyante svacittadharmatāyāṃ ca cittam avasthitaṃ bhavati / yadaivaṃ vijñaptimātratāyāṃ cittam avasthitaṃ bhavati tadā kathaṃ vyapadiśyata ity āha /
column2: For in this way the even, objectless, undifferentiated transcendent knowledge arises, the residues of the inveterate division of subject and object disappear, and the citta stands firmly in the dharmatā of its citta.If the citta is established in pure consciousness, what is its name?

column1: acitto 'nupalambo 'sau jñānaṃ lokottarañ ca tat / āśrayasya parāvṛttir dvidhādauṣṭhulyahānitaḥ // 29
column2: To which he replies: He is without citta, without perception, his knowledge is transcendent; the transformation of its substratum takes place because the double unfitness disappeared.

column1: sa evānāsravo dhātur acintyaḥ kuśalo dhruvaḥ / sukho vimuktikāyo 'sau dharmākhyo 'yaṃ mahāmuneḥ // 30
column2: It is the 'purified' dhätu, unthinkable, good, constant, the blissful vimuktikaya, the dharmakaya of the great Muni.

column1: iti / tad anena ślokadvayena darśanamārgam ārabhyottaraviśeṣagatyā phalasaṃpattir udbhāvitā vijñaptimātratāpraviṣṭayoginaḥ /
column2: Through these two stanzas it is demonstrated that the yogin, who has penetrated the vijnaptimātra, attains full possession of concentration from the path of knowledge through higher and higher phases. The bhāvanāmarga is referred to below.

column1: cācitto 'nupalambho 'sau / (29a)
column2: About both margas cf. Abh. citta, without perception'.

column1: anucitatvāl loke samudācārābhāvān nirvikalpatvāc ca lokād uttīrṇam iti jñānaṃ lokottarañ ca tad iti / (29b) tasya jñānasyānantaraṃ āśrayasya parāvṛttir bhavatīti jñāpanārtham āha /
column2: Since his knowledge does not appear in the world as inadequate to it and is indifferent, it is superior to the world; therefore his knowledge is transcendent'.To indicate that the immediately preceding substratum of this knowledge undergoes a transformation, he says: 'the transformation of its substratum'.

column1: āśrayo 'tra sarvabījakam ālayavijñānam /
column2: The substratum here is the alayavijnana, which contains the germs of everything;

column1: tasya parāvṛttir yā dauṣṭhulyavipākadvayavāsanābhāvena nivṛttau satyāṃ karmaṇyatādharmakāyādvayajñānabhāvena parāvṛttiḥ /
column2: its transformation is the transformation in the form of activity (karmaṇyatā), dharmakaya and secondless knowledge of what would materialize (nirvṛttau satyām) in the form of latent impressions of the dual effect of unfitness (dauşthulya).

column1: sā punar āśrayaparāvṛttiḥ kasya prahāṇāt prāpyate / ata āha /
column2: When shrinking, what is the transformation of the substrate achieved from?

column1: dvidheti kleśāvaraṇadauṣṭhulyaṃ jñeyāvaraṇadauṣṭhulyañ ca /
column2: Answer: 'because the double unfitness disappeared'. 'twice' as unfitness due to the kleśâvarana and the jneyâvaraņa.

column1: dauṣṭhulyam āśrayasyākarmaṇyatā / tat punaḥ kleśajñeyāvaraṇayor bījam /
column2: Unfitness is the inertia of the substratum, and is the germ of kleśa and jneyaavarana.

column1: sā punar āśrayaparāvṛttiḥ śrāvakādigatadauṣṭhulyahānitaś ca prāpyate yad āha vimuktikāya iti /
column2: And this transformation of the substratum is attained by the disappearance of the unfitness in the Śrāvaka; therefore he says: 'vimuktikaya'.

column1: bodhisattvagatadauṣṭhulyahānitaś ca prāpyate yad āha
column2: And it is attained through the disappearance of the unfitness in the Bodhisattva;

column1: dharmākhyo 'yaṃ mahāmuner iti / (30d) dvidhā āvaraṇabhedena sottarā niruttarā cāśrayaparāvṛttir uktā /
column2: therefore he says: 'the dharmakaya of the great Muni'.According to the two avaranas, there is a next highest and highest upheaval.

column1: atra gāthā / jñeyam ādānavijñānaṃ dvayāvaraṇalakṣaṇam / sarvabījaṃ kleśabījaṃ bandhas tatra dvayor dvayoḥ //
column2: About this the following saying: 'Know that the adanavijnana is characterized by two kinds of avaranas, it contains the germ of klesas and the germ of all avaranas; both of them are bound by it.'

column1: iti / dvayor iti śrāvakabodhisattvayoḥ / ādyasya kleśabījaṃ itarasya dvayāvaraṇabījaṃ tadudghātāt sarvajñatāvāptir bhavatīti /
column2: Namely the Sravaka and the Bodhisattva; the former has that containing the germ of klesas, the latter that containing the germ of both; by its explosion omniscience is attained.

column1: sa evānāsravo dhātur iti (30a)
column2: It is the uncontaminated dhatu'.

column1: sa evāśrayaparāvṛttirūpaḥ / anāsravo dhātur ity ucyate nirdauṣṭhulyatvāt /
column2: It is this transformation of the substratum that is called the uncontaminated dhatu'.

column1: āryadharmahetutvād dhātuḥ / hetvartho hy atra dhātuśabdaḥ /
column2: As the ground for the aryadharma, it is dhatu; for here the word dhatu has the meaning of reason.

column1: acintyas tarkāgocaratvāt pratyātmavedyatvād dṛṣṭāntābhāvāc ca /
column2: 'unthinkable' because it is not open to reflection, has to be experienced by the individual and is without precedent.

column1: kuśalo viśuddhālambanatvāt kṣematvād anāsravadharmamayatvāc ca /
column2: 'good' because he has a pure object, is blissful, and consists of uncontaminated dharmas.

column1: dhruvo nityatvād akṣayatayā / sukho nityatvād eva yad anityaṃ tad duḥkhaṃ ayaṃ ca nitya iti tasmāt sukhaḥ /
column2: 'constant' because it is eternal by virtue of its imperishability.'blissful' (sukha) precisely because he is eternal; what is not eternal is sorrowful, and this one is eternal, therefore it is full of bliss.

column1: kleśāvaraṇaprahāṇāc chrāvakāṇāṃ vimuktikāyaḥ /
column2: Because of the depletion of the kleśa-avaraņas, he is the vimuktikāya of the Śrāvakas.

column1: sa evāśrayaparāvṛttilakṣaṇo dharmākhyo 'py ucyate mahāmuner bhūmipāramitābhāvanayā kleśajñeyāvaraṇaprahāṇāt / āśrayaparāvṛttisamudāgamān mahāmuner dharmakāya ity ucyate /
column2: The very same, which consists in the transformation of the substratum, is also called the one called dharma (viz. kaya). 'of the great Muni': because as a result of the concentration (bhāvanā) bhūmipāramita, etc. , the klesa and jneya-avaraṇas have disappeared, (and consequently) the transformation of the substratum has appeared, it is called the dharmakaya of the great Muni.

column1: saṃsārāparityāgāt tadanupasaṃkleśatvād bodhisattvānāṃ sarvadharmavibhutvalābhataś ca dharmakāya ity ucyate /
column2: Because it is immanent in samsāra (aparityāga) and because all dharmas not infected by it attain infinity (vibhutva), it is called dharmakaya.

column1: mahāmuner iti paramauneyayogād buddho bhagavān mahāmunir iti //
column2: 'of the great Muni' because he has the highest Muni qualification, is Buddha the Exalted, the great Muni.
